sen.j: 板倉 勝重（いたくら かつしげ）は、安土桃山時代から江戸時代の大名、京都所司代である。
sen.e: Katsushige ITAKURA was Kyoto Shoshidai (Kyoto Deputy), a daimyo (Japanese feudal lord) from the Azuchi-Momoyama period to the Edo period.
Katsushige ITAKURA was a daimyo (Japanese feudal lord) from the Azuchi-Momoyama period to the Edo period, and served as the deputy (Shoshidai) of Kyoto.

sen.j: 父は板倉好重、母は本多光重の娘。

sen.j: 三河国額田郡小美村（現在の愛知県岡崎市）に生まれる。
sen.e: He was born in Oimura, Nukata district, Mikawa Province(current Okazaki City, Aichi Prefecture).

sen.j: 幼少時に出家して浄土真宗の永安寺の僧となった。
sen.e: When he was a child, he renounced the world and became a priest of Yoan-ji Temple of Jodo Shinshu (an offshoot of the Jodo Templesect).
When he was a child, he renounced the world and became a Buddhist priest in the Jodo Shinshu sect (an offshoot of the Jodoshu sect), attached to Yoan-ji Temple.

sen.j: ところが1561年（永禄4年）に父の好重が善明提の戦いで戦死、さらに家督を継いだ弟の板倉定重も1581年（天正9年）に武田氏軍の籠る遠江国・高天神城攻め（高天神城の戦い）で戦死したために徳川家康の命で家督を相続した。
sen.e: However, his father Yoshishige was killed in the battle of Zemmyo tsutsumi in the Eiroku era, and his brother Sadashige ITAKURA, who had taken over as head of the Family, was also killed in the battle of Takatenjin-jo Castle in Totomi Province where the army of the Takeda clan had hidden themselves in 1581, which resulted in Katsushige taking over as head of the Family on Ieyasu TOKUGAWA's orders.

sen.j: その後は主に施政面に従事し、1586年（天正14年）には家康が浜松城より駿府城へ移った際には駿府町奉行、1590年（天正18年）に家康が関東へ移封されると、武蔵国新座郡・豊島郡で1,000石を給され、関東代官、江戸町奉行となる。
sen.e: Then he was mainly engaged in administrative policy, and in 1586 when Ieyasu moved from Hamamatsu-jo Castle to Sumbu-jo Castle, he became a town magistrate of Sumbu, in 1590 when Ieyasu's territory was moved to the Kanto region he became governor of Kanto and town magistrate of Edo, given 1,000 koku in Niikura district and Toyoshima district, Musashi Province.

Thereafter he was engaged primarily in implementing administrative policy, and in 1586 when Ieyasu moved from Hamamatsu-jo Castle to Sumbu-jo Castle, he became the town magistrate of Sumbu; in 1590, when Ieyasu's territory was moved to the Kanto region, he became the governor of Kanto and the town magistrate of Edo, receiving fiefs amounting to 1,000 koku in the disctricts of Niikura and Toyoshima, Musashi Province.

Thereafter he was engaged primarily in implementing administrative policy, and in 1586 when Ieyasu moved from Hamamatsu-jo Castle to Sunpu-jo Castle, he became the Sunpu machi-bugyo (town magistrate of Sunpu); in 1590, when Ieyasu's territory was moved to the Kanto region, he became the Kanto daikan (governor of Kanto) and the Edo machi-bugyo (town magistrate of Sunpu), receiving fiefs amounting to 1,000 koku in the districts of Niikura and Toyoshima, Musashi Province.
sen.cmt: 駿府町奉行、関東代官、江戸町奉行 の日本語読みを追加しました。スペルを修正しました。

sen.j: 関ヶ原の戦い後の1601年（慶長6年）、三河国3郡に6,600石を与えられるとともに京都町奉行（のち京都所司代）に任命され、京都の治安維持と朝廷の掌握、さらに大坂城の豊臣家の監視に当たった。
sen.e: In 1601 after the Battle of Sekigaharaduring the Keicho era, he was given 6,600 koku in 3 districts of Mikawa Province, and at the same time he was appointed as town magistrate of Kyoto (Kyoto Shoshidai [Kyoto Deputy] in later years), took control of maintaining security in Kyoto City, grasped Imperial Court, and then monitored the Toyotomi family of Osaka-jo Castle.

In 1601, after the Battle of Sekigaharaduring the Keicho era, he was given fiefs amounting to 6,600 koku in 3 districts of Mikawa Province, and at the same time he was appointed as town magistrate of Kyoto (and later the Kyoto Deputy (Shoshidai)); he assumed responsibilty for maintaining security in the city of Kyoto, reporting on developments at the Imperial Court, and monitoring the Toyotomi family of Osaka-jo Castle.

sen.cmt: 京都町奉行 の日本語読みを追加しました。スペルを修正しました。

sen.j: 1603年（慶長8年）、徳川家康が征夷大将軍に就任して江戸幕府を開いた際に従五位下伊賀国守に叙任され、1609年（慶長14年）には近江国・山城国に領地を加増され1万6,600石余を知行、大名に列している。
sen.e: In 1603 when Ieyasu Tokugawa assumed the title of seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") and established the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), he was ordained ju go i ge, (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade), director of Iga, and in 1609 he was given more territory in Omi Province and Yamashiro Province with more than 6,600 koku as enfeoffment and was raised to Daimyo.

In 1603, when Ieyasu Tokugawa assumed the title of Seiitaishogun (literally, "Great general who subdues the barbarians") and established the Edo bakufu (feudal government headed by a shogun), he was awarded the coutr rank of Ju-go-i-ge, (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade), appointed as director of Iga Province, and in 1609 he was given more territory in the provinces of Omi and Yamashiro, whereupon he was rasied in status to Daimyo, with fiefs amounting to more than 6,600 koku.
sen.cmt: grammar, inconsistent title/capitalization, some unclear portions
sen.e: In 1603, when Ieyasu TOKUGAWA assumed the title of Seii taishogun (literally, "Great general who subdues the barbarians") and established the Edo bakufu (feudal government headed by a shogun), he was awarded the court rank of Jugoinoge, (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade), appointed as Iga no kuni no Kami (officer in charge of regional administration in Iga), and in 1609 he was given more territory in the provinces of Omi and Yamashiro, whereupon he was raised in status to Daimyo, with fiefs amounting to more than 16,600 koku.
